content.raw: I'm not sure that I like having the results of "tags" listed, since it's a subset of the versions and won't include branch names.
content.html: I'm not sure that I like having the results of "tags" listed, since it's a subset of the versions and won't include branch names.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: With no arguments, `hg up -C` will update along the DAG to the next head.
content.html: With no arguments, hg up -C will update along the DAG to the next head.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: This looks mostly fine to me, but I think this should be the last time we modify this code -- future versions should *only* use `hglib`, which will be more reliable, and which comes with yt in the install script.
content.html: This looks mostly fine to me, but I think this should be the last time we modify this code -- future versions should only use hglib, which will be more reliable, and which comes with yt in the install script.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: I agree we should switch to using ``hglib`` in the future, but I think this is a good ultimate version of this functionality.
content.html: I agree we should switch to using hglib in the future, but I think this is a good ultimate version of this functionality.

content.raw: Now I'm hesitant to push this through. I haven't tested it on all of the different types of machines or installation methods.
content.html: Now I'm hesitant to push this through. I haven't tested it on all of the different types of machines or installation methods.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: The absolute *only* time this should *ever* work is with the install script.  We cannot and should not attempt to make it work anywhere else.  If you have tested it one place with the install script, that is sufficient.
content.html: The absolute only time this should ever work is with the install script. We cannot and should not attempt to make it work anywhere else. If you have tested it one place with the install script, that is sufficient.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
Let me remove the tag listing stuff and i'll just hardcode to update to yt-2.x, yt or stable, and i'll test it again.  then we can patch it into all three heads so people can switch between.

The only thing I thought I was noticing was that it wasn't picking up on when changes had been made to the repo (i.e. changeset+) when I did "yt version", but then when I went back to the original head, it *still* wasn't.  Perhaps it was because I tested this by using "python setup.py install" instead of "python setup.py develop"?  Not sure.  Hence my hesitation at pushing it through.
content.html:
Let me remove the tag listing stuff and i'll just hardcode to update to yt-2.x, yt or stable, and i'll test it again. then we can patch it into all three heads so people can switch between.

The only thing I thought I was noticing was that it wasn't picking up on when changes had been made to the repo (i.e. changeset+) when I did "yt version", but then when I went back to the original head, it still wasn't. Perhaps it was because I tested this by using "python setup.py install" instead of "python setup.py develop"? Not sure. Hence my hesitation at pushing it through.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: Yeah, it *only* works with "develop."
content.html: Yeah, it only works with "develop."

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
Can you confirm that "yt version" still yields a + after the version if you make mods to the repo on the tip right now?

Is there any reason that running "python setup.py install" would mess that up, even if following that, one ran "python setup.py develop"?
content.html:
Can you confirm that "yt version" still yields a + after the version if you make mods to the repo on the tip right now?

Is there any reason that running "python setup.py install" would mess that up, even if following that, one ran "python setup.py develop"?

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
The difference here is that any time you run "install" instead of develop,
you are no longer using the files in the hg repository.  And, yt only knows
how to find which files you are running.  Running develop does an in-place
setup.
content.html: The difference here is that any time you run "install" instead of develop, you are no longer using the files in the hg repository. And, yt only knows how to find which files you are running. Running develop does an in-place setup.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: That is what I thought, but does running "develop" after that switch back and fix the problem?  And can you confirm?  Because even on tip, mine still does not show + after changsets, even though I've re-run setup.py develop.
content.html: That is what I thought, but does running "develop" after that switch back and fix the problem? And can you confirm? Because even on tip, mine still does not show + after changsets, even though I've re-run setup.py develop.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: You probably have to uninstall it with "pip uninstall" first.
content.html: You probably have to uninstall it with "pip uninstall" first.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
I'm confused.  I never installed yt with pip.  

In order to test out this PR, Nathan suggested that I needed to make sure that this PR worked when people had run "python setup.py install" instead of just "python setup.py develop".  So I took my standard yt install on my local box, which had been installed using the bash installer script, and i ran "python setup.py install" on it.  After this, I found that when I run "yt version", it doesn't show me when there have been modifications to the repository by adding a "+" to the end of the changeid, even though when I run "hg id" it *does* reveal that "+" on the end of the changeid.  So now, even when I've run "python setup.py develop" again, it continues to show this behavior even on the tip of the repo. I don't know what is going on, and I want to make sure others don't suffer from this problem.
content.html:
I'm confused. I never installed yt with pip.

In order to test out this PR, Nathan suggested that I needed to make sure that this PR worked when people had run "python setup.py install" instead of just "python setup.py develop". So I took my standard yt install on my local box, which had been installed using the bash installer script, and i ran "python setup.py install" on it. After this, I found that when I run "yt version", it doesn't show me when there have been modifications to the repository by adding a "+" to the end of the changeid, even though when I run "hg id" it does reveal that "+" on the end of the changeid. So now, even when I've run "python setup.py develop" again, it continues to show this behavior even on the tip of the repo. I don't know what is going on, and I want to make sure others don't suffer from this problem.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: Just to clarify, I said to check to make sure it *doesn't* work and fails hard with a useful error message with setup.py install.
content.html: Just to clarify, I said to check to make sure it doesn't work and fails hard with a useful error message with setup.py install.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: One other issue, aren't we implicitly creating a derived work of mercurial (and thus breaking the GPL) by using the mercurial internal API like this?
content.html: One other issue, aren't we implicitly creating a derived work of mercurial (and thus breaking the GPL) by using the mercurial internal API like this?

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: @ngoldbaum has also confirmed that "yt version" does not give you the + on the end of changeset ids on the tip, so it does not appear to be isolated to my install.  But this is a bug not isolated to this PR.  I'm trying to fix it.
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum has also confirmed that "yt version" does not give you the + on the end of changeset ids on the tip, so it does not appear to be isolated to my install. But this is a bug not isolated to this PR. I'm trying to fix it.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
Moving to hglib would remedy any potential GPL issues.  However, I believe
we are in compliance as long as we make good on any offer to distribute the
source.  I do not want "yt update" to be a blocker or a bottleneck here.
content.html: Moving to hglib would remedy any potential GPL issues. However, I believe we are in compliance as long as we make good on any offer to distribute the source. I do not want "yt update" to be a blocker or a bottleneck here.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw:
pip will uninstall anything that is installed.  There is no "python2.7
setup.py uninstall" command.  pip serves that purpose.
content.html: pip will uninstall anything that is installed. There is no "python2.7 setup.py uninstall" command. pip serves that purpose.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

content.raw: Please do not merge this in before the release of yt-3.0.  Nathan points out, quite rightly, that we should have this thoroughly tested between all of us before goign gold.  I don't want to be responsible for breaking yt update with the biggest release we've had to date because it got accepted a few hours before release with relatively little testing.
content.html: Please do not merge this in before the release of yt-3.0. Nathan points out, quite rightly, that we should have this thoroughly tested between all of us before goign gold. I don't want to be responsible for breaking yt update with the biggest release we've had to date because it got accepted a few hours before release with relatively little testing.

pullrequest.title: Updating the "yt update" command to allow switching to any arbitrary tag or revision (and rebuilding afterwards)

reason: Happily, it looks like this functionality is lower priority since the transition went well.  Thank you for the effort, Cameron!
description:
This introduces new functionality which allows for:


```
#!python

yt update --version=yt-3.0

```

to automatically switch to the yt-3.0 branch and then rebuild.

It also includes


```
#!python

yt update --list
```


to display the results of "hg tags" to show what are valid versions to which one could update.

It seems to work fine, but I've only tested it on a few machines that had yt installed via the installer script.

I thought this would help new users in switching over from old versions of yt to 3.0 and back if need be, but it probably needs some more testing before widespread use.  Note, I have not included documentation as of yet, but I'm happy to do so if people think this is a worthwhile addition.
